audit_report:
1. YES
2. - Type: Incorrect constructor / Unprotected initialization leading to ownership takeover and fund drain.
   - Vulnerable lines: "function missing() public { O = msg.sender; }" and "function w() public x { O.transfer(this.balance); }"
   - Reason: In Solidity 0.4.24 the constructor must be named exactly "Missing"; "missing" is a public function callable by anyone at any time, allowing any caller to set O to themselves and then call w() (gated by x) to transfer all Ether to O; also, there is no one-time initialization guard, so ownership can be reset later.

1) YES.
2) Solidity: function Constructor() public { owner = msg.sender; } is not a constructor in ^0.4.24 (constructor keyword required, and pre-0.4.22 constructors must match contract name), so anyone can call it to seize ownership; this also leaves owner uninitialized until called, risking stuck funds if never set; withdraw() then lets the attacker drain via onlyowner. Python: ctypes.CDLL('./missing.dll') uses a relative path enabling DLL search order hijacking, and calls to self.dll.Constructor()/withdraw() lack argtypes/restype, risking unsafe FFI behavior.
3) N/A. 4) N/A.

1. YES
2. - Solidity: Ownership takeover – lines: "function initWallet() public { creator = msg.sender; }" (no constructor/one-time guard); anyone can set/reset creator at any time. 
   - Solidity: Full-balance drain – lines: "function migrateTo(address to) public { require(creator == msg.sender); to.transfer(this.balance); }"; combined with the above lets an attacker become creator and drain all ETH. 
   - Solidity: CEI violation/withdrawal DoS – lines: "msg.sender.transfer(amount); balances[msg.sender] -= amount;" and "to.transfer(this.balance)"; using transfer before state change and 2300-gas stipend can brick withdrawals/migration for contract recipients (DoS). 
   - Python: DLL/shared-library hijacking – line: "c_lib = ctypes.CDLL('./wallet_c_lib.so')" loads a relative path library, enabling arbitrary code execution if the working directory is attacker-controlled. 
   - Python: Unsafe ctypes invocation – line: "c_lib.some_function()" without setting argtypes/restype risks memory corruption/crashes and exploitation with mismatched or malicious libraries.
3. N/A
4. N/A

1. YES.
2. Vulnerabilities: Unrestricted withdrawals (lines 9–15) — withdrawTokens/withdrawEther are public, letting anyone trigger full drains to owner (centralization/grief risk); Unchecked external call returns (lines 11, 18) — ignores ERC‑20 transfer/call success, risking stuck tokens or unexpected behavior; Low‑level call reentrancy/gas grief (lines 16–19) — addr.call with all gas in a user‑controlled loop enables reentrancy into this contract and can exhaust gas; Unbounded loop/integer overflow DoS (lines 16–19) — user‑supplied num and i++ can overflow or run until out‑of‑gas; Legacy constructor pattern/outdated compiler (lines 1, 8) — name‑based constructor without visibility on ^0.4.19 is fragile and error‑prone if renamed/miscompiled; External token reentrancy vector (line 11) — calling untrusted token.transfer before any effects lets a malicious token reenter; Python unsafe dynamic library load (line 32) — ctypes loads ./library.so from a relative path allowing arbitrary code execution if the file is replaced.
3. N/A.
4. N/A.

1. YES.
2. DoS with failed refund (lines 7-9: require(externalSend(currentFrontrunner, currentBid))) allows the previous frontrunner to block all future bids by reverting or exhausting gas; Reentrancy (line 8 before lines 10-11) because the external call occurs before state updates, allowing the previous frontrunner’s fallback to re-enter bid() and then the outer call overwrites newer state, breaking invariants; mitigate with pull-payments and checks-effects-interactions/ReentrancyGuard.
3/4. N/A.
